rizal-law.title: Rizal Law
rizal-law.description: Questions about Republic Act 1425 and its provisions

questions.question: What is the official name of the Rizal Law?
questions.explanation: The Rizal Law is officially known as Republic Act 1425, enacted on June 12, 1956.

questions.question: Who authored the Rizal Law?
questions.explanation: Senator Claro M. Recto authored the Rizal Law to promote nationalism among Filipino students.

questions.question: The Rizal Law mandates the teaching of Rizal's works in which educational levels?
questions.explanation: The Rizal Law requires the teaching of Rizal's life and works in both high school and college curricula.

questions.question: Which two novels are specifically mentioned in the Rizal Law as required reading?
options: Noli Me Tangere and El Filibusterismo
Mi Último Adiós and The Indolence
Noli Me Tangere and Mi Último Adiós
El Filibusterismo and The Philippines a Century Hence
questions.explanation: The Rizal Law specifically mandates the reading of Noli Me Tangere and El Filibusterismo.

questions.question: What was the main opposition to the Rizal Law?
questions.explanation: The Catholic Church was the main opposition to the Rizal Law, arguing that Rizal's novels were anti-Catholic.

questions.question: Who was the President of the Philippines when the Rizal Law was signed?
questions.explanation: President Ramon Magsaysay signed the Rizal Law (Republic Act 1425) into law on June 12, 1956.

questions.question: What compromise was made to pass the Rizal Law?
options: Rizal's novels could be read in Filipino translation only
Only excerpts of the novels needed to be read
Reading of unexpurgated versions was not required
The law would only apply to public schools
questions.explanation: A compromise was made allowing schools to use expurgated (edited) versions of Rizal's novels rather than requiring the complete, unexpurgated versions.

questions.question: According to the Rizal Law, what should be established in all schools?
questions.explanation: The Rizal Law mandates the establishment of Rizal libraries in all schools to house his works and related materials.

early-life.title: Early Life
early-life.description: Questions about Rizal's childhood and family background

questions.question: What was José Rizal's complete full name?
options: José Protasio Rizal Mercado y Alonso Realonda
questions.explanation: José Rizal's complete full name was José Protasio Rizal Mercado y Alonso Realonda.

questions.question: On what day of the week was Rizal born?
questions.explanation: José Rizal was born on Wednesday, June 19, 1861.

questions.question: What was Rizal's father's occupation?
questions.explanation: Francisco Mercado Rizal was a successful farmer and businessman who owned rice fields and other agricultural lands.

questions.question: Which sister was Rizal's confidante who remained unmarried?
questions.explanation: Trinidad (nicknamed Trining) was José's confidante and remained unmarried throughout her life.

questions.question: Which sister died young and was deeply mourned by José?
questions.explanation: Concepcion (nicknamed Concha) died young, and her death deeply affected José who mourned her loss.

questions.question: What was the name of Rizal's only brother?
questions.explanation: Paciano was Rizal's only brother and served as his mentor, supporter, and political guide.

questions.question: From whom did Rizal receive his first formal education?
questions.explanation: Teodora Alonzo, Rizal's mother, was his first teacher who taught him reading, writing, prayers, and moral values.

questions.question: At what age did Rizal make his first pilgrimage to Antipolo?
questions.explanation: Rizal was 7 years old when he made his first pilgrimage to Antipolo on June 6, 1868, as part of his mother's vow to the Virgin of Antipolo.

questions.question: What early interest did young Rizal develop that influenced his scientific pursuits?
questions.explanation: Young Rizal loved collecting insects, shells, and stones, which developed his interest in natural history and scientific observation.

questions.question: Which family member most influenced Rizal's political awareness and nationalism?
questions.explanation: Paciano, his older brother, was instrumental in developing Rizal's political awareness, nationalism, and understanding of social injustices.

education.title: Education
education.description: Questions about Rizal's academic journey and achievements

questions.question: Who was Rizal's teacher at Biñan School?
questions.explanation: Maestro Justiniano Aquino Cruz was Rizal's teacher at the private school in Biñan, Laguna.

questions.question: How long did Rizal study at Biñan School?
questions.explanation: Rizal studied at Biñan School for about 1 year and 5 months, from June 1869 to December 1870.

questions.question: With whom did Rizal stay while studying in Biñan?
questions.explanation: While studying in Biñan, Rizal stayed with his aunt's family, specifically Tía Isabel.

questions.question: What was Rizal's academic performance at Ateneo Municipal?
questions.explanation: Rizal was consistently first in class at Ateneo Municipal and received numerous awards and medals for his excellence.

questions.question: What religious organization was Rizal a member of at Ateneo?
questions.explanation: Rizal was a member of the Marian Congregation during his time at Ateneo Municipal de Manila.

questions.question: What grade did Rizal achieve when he graduated from Ateneo?
questions.explanation: Rizal graduated from Ateneo with 'Sobresaliente' (Excellent) in all subjects and received highest honors.

questions.question: Which courses did Rizal take at the University of Santo Tomas?
options: Philosophy and Letters, Medicine, and Surveying
questions.explanation: At UST, Rizal took Philosophy and Letters (1877-1879), Medicine (1878-1882), and Surveying (1879-1882).

questions.question: What was the title of Rizal's medical dissertation in Madrid?
questions.explanation: Rizal's medical dissertation was titled 'The Treatment of Madness' when he earned his Doctor of Medicine degree.

questions.question: What grade did Rizal receive for his medical degree in Madrid?
questions.explanation: Rizal graduated with the grade 'Notable' (Very Good) when he completed his medical degree at Universidad Central de Madrid.

questions.question: In which medical specialty did Rizal focus his studies?
questions.explanation: Rizal specialized in ophthalmology (eye diseases and surgery) during his medical studies in Europe.

questions.question: Why did Rizal leave the University of Santo Tomas before completing his degree?
questions.explanation: Rizal left UST due to discrimination against Filipino students, outdated teaching methods, and limited access to modern facilities.

questions.question: What additional subjects did Rizal study in Europe besides medicine?
options: Philosophy, History, Modern languages, Art, and Sculpture
questions.explanation: Besides medicine, Rizal studied Philosophy and Letters, History and Geography, Modern languages (French, German), Art and painting, and Sculpture and clay modeling.

travels.title: Travels
travels.description: Questions about Rizal's journeys around the world

questions.question: What was the name of the ship Rizal took on his first voyage to Europe?
questions.explanation: Rizal boarded the Spanish steamer Salvadora when he secretly left the Philippines on May 3, 1882.

questions.question: What name did Rizal use when he first traveled to Europe?
questions.explanation: To keep his departure secret from his parents, Rizal used the name 'José Mercado' during his first trip to Europe.

questions.question: Through which famous canal did Rizal's ship pass on his way to Europe?
questions.explanation: Rizal's ship passed through the Suez Canal in Egypt, which connected the Mediterranean and Red Seas.

questions.question: What did Rizal do as Manila's skyline disappeared during his departure?
questions.explanation: As Manila disappeared from view, Rizal sketched the city's skyline as a farewell memento of his homeland.

questions.question: In which country did Rizal visit the cities of Colombo and Point Galle?
questions.explanation: Rizal visited Colombo and Point Galle in Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) on May 17-18, 1882.

questions.question: What was special about Rizal's first pilgrimage to Antipolo?
options: It was part of his mother's vow
He wrote his first poem there
questions.explanation: The pilgrimage to Antipolo was part of his mother's vow to the Virgin of Antipolo for thanksgiving for safe childbirth.

questions.question: What festival did Rizal witness during his pilgrimage to Pakil?
questions.explanation: During his pilgrimage to Pakil in 1881, Rizal witnessed the famous Turumba festival with people dancing in the streets.

questions.question: Which ship took Rizal from Biñan back to Calamba?
questions.explanation: On December 17, 1870, Rizal took the steamer Talim from Biñan back to Calamba after completing his studies.

questions.question: In which German cities did Rizal stay during his European travels?
questions.explanation: During his time in Germany (1885-1887), Rizal stayed in Berlin, Leipzig, and Heidelberg.

questions.question: What did Rizal collect as souvenirs during his return from Biñan?
questions.explanation: Young Rizal collected pebbles as souvenirs during his journey back from Biñan to Calamba.

questions.question: Through which Italian port did Rizal first enter Europe?
questions.explanation: Rizal first arrived in Europe through the Italian port of Naples on June 11, 1882.

questions.question: What was the duration of Rizal's first European journey?
questions.explanation: Rizal's first European journey lasted about 5 years, from 1882 to 1887.

works.title: Literary Works
works.description: Questions about Rizal's novels, essays, and poems

questions.question: When was 'Noli Me Tangere' first published?
questions.explanation: Noli Me Tangere was first published in 1887 in Berlin, Germany.

questions.question: Who is the love interest of Crisóstomo Ibarra in Noli Me Tangere?
questions.explanation: María Clara is Crisóstomo Ibarra's love interest and childhood sweetheart in Noli Me Tangere.

questions.question: What is the subtitle of El Filibusterismo?
questions.explanation: El Filibusterismo's subtitle is 'The Reign of Greed', highlighting the corruption and greed in colonial society.

questions.question: Which character represents the tragic Filipino mother in Noli Me Tangere?
questions.explanation: Sisa represents the tragic Filipino mother whose sons were falsely accused, leading to her mental breakdown.

questions.question: What is Simoun's true identity in El Filibusterismo?
questions.explanation: Simoun is actually Crisóstomo Ibarra in disguise, having survived the events of the first novel.

questions.question: At what age did Rizal write 'A La Juventud Filipina' (To the Filipino Youth)?
questions.explanation: Rizal wrote 'A La Juventud Filipina' when he was only 18 years old, and it won first prize in a literary contest.

questions.question: What does the essay 'The Indolence of the Filipino' defend against?
questions.explanation: The essay defends Filipinos against Spanish accusations of laziness, arguing that oppression caused apparent indolence.

questions.question: How many possible futures for the Philippines did Rizal discuss in 'The Philippines a Century Hence'?
questions.explanation: Rizal discussed three possibilities: remaining a Spanish colony, being absorbed by another nation, or achieving independence.

questions.question: Who is the antagonist friar in Noli Me Tangere?
questions.explanation: Padre Dámaso is the main antagonist friar in Noli Me Tangere, representing corrupt clergy and colonial abuse.

questions.question: When was 'Mi Último Adiós' written?
options: On the eve of his execution
questions.explanation: Mi Último Adiós (My Last Farewell) was written on the eve of Rizal's execution on December 29, 1896.

questions.question: Which character in El Filibusterismo represents the idealistic student?
questions.explanation: Isagani represents the idealistic poet and student who believes in peaceful reform rather than violent revolution.

questions.question: What is the relationship between María Clara and Padre Dámaso in Noli Me Tangere?
questions.explanation: A shocking revelation in the novel is that Padre Dámaso is actually María Clara's biological father, not Don Rafael Ibarra.

exile.title: Exile in Dapitan
exile.description: Questions about Rizal's exile period from 1892-1896

questions.question: On what exact date did Rizal arrive in Dapitan?
questions.explanation: Rizal arrived in Dapitan on July 17, 1892, beginning his four-year exile.

questions.question: Who was the Spanish commandant of Dapitan during Rizal's exile?
questions.explanation: Captain Ricardo Carnicero was the Spanish commandant who became Rizal's friend and protector during his exile.

questions.question: What school did Rizal establish in Dapitan?
questions.explanation: Rizal established the Talisay School, which became known for its progressive teaching methods.

questions.question: What agricultural venture did Rizal pursue in Dapitan?
questions.explanation: Rizal engaged in rice farming, coconut plantation, and abaca cultivation to improve the local economy.

questions.question: What lottery ticket did Rizal win while in Dapitan?
questions.explanation: Rizal won the Spanish National Lottery, which provided him with financial resources for his projects.

questions.question: What scientific work did Rizal do in Dapitan?
questions.explanation: Rizal conducted extensive botanical and zoological research, collecting and studying various species in Mindanao.

questions.question: Who was Rizal's Irish friend who visited him in Dapitan?
questions.explanation: A.B. Meyer, an Irish scientist and ethnologist, visited Rizal in Dapitan and became his friend and correspondent.

questions.question: What was the name of Rizal's house in Dapitan?
questions.explanation: Rizal's house in Dapitan was called 'Casa Redonda' (Round House) due to its unique octagonal shape.

questions.question: What clinic did Rizal establish for his medical practice?
questions.explanation: Rizal established a clinic in his own house where he treated patients, including both locals and Spanish officials.

questions.question: What was Rizal's contribution to Dapitan's infrastructure besides the water system?
questions.explanation: Rizal contributed to street lighting, public plaza beautification, and road improvements throughout Dapitan.

martyrdom.title: Martyrdom
martyrdom.description: Questions about Rizal's trial, execution, and final moments

questions.question: Who was Rizal's defense lawyer during his trial?
questions.explanation: Lt. Luis Taviel de Andrade, a Spanish military officer, served as Rizal's defense lawyer during his court-martial.

questions.question: At what time was Rizal executed?
questions.explanation: José Rizal was executed by firing squad at exactly 7:03 AM on December 30, 1896.

questions.question: How many Spanish soldiers were in the firing squad?
questions.explanation: The firing squad consisted of 8 Spanish soldiers from the 70th Regiment of Native Infantry.

questions.question: What was the original name of the execution site (now Rizal Park)?
questions.explanation: The execution site was originally called Bagumbayan, which is now known as Rizal Park or Luneta.

questions.question: What did Rizal refuse to do before his execution?
options: Face away from the firing squad
questions.explanation: Rizal refused to face away from the firing squad, preferring to face his executioners, but was forced to turn around.

questions.question: Who was allowed to visit Rizal on his last night?
questions.explanation: On his last night, Rizal was visited by his family members, his defense lawyers, and Jesuit priests.

questions.question: What did Rizal give to his sister Trinidad before his execution?
options: An alcohol cooking stove with his poem hidden inside
questions.explanation: Rizal gave his sister Trinidad an alcohol cooking stove with his final poem 'Mi Último Adiós' hidden inside.

questions.question: What was Rizal wearing during his execution?
questions.explanation: Rizal was dressed in a black suit, white shirt, black shoes, and a bowler hat during his execution.

questions.question: Who presided over Rizal's court-martial?
questions.explanation: Colonel José Togores Fábrega presided over Rizal's court-martial trial.

questions.question: What was the duration of Rizal's trial?
questions.explanation: Rizal's trial lasted only three days, from December 26-28, 1896, before he was sentenced to death.

questions.question: What happened to Rizal's body immediately after execution?
questions.explanation: After execution, Rizal's body was taken to Paco Cemetery where it was buried in an unmarked grave.

questions.question: Who among Rizal's family witnessed his execution?
questions.explanation: None of Rizal's family members were allowed to witness his execution by the Spanish authorities.

19th-century.title: 19th Century Philippines
19th-century.description: Questions about the historical context of the Philippines during the Spanish colonial period

questions.question: Who appointed the Governor-General of the Philippines during Spanish colonial rule?
questions.explanation: The Governor-General was appointed by the Spanish monarch and served as the highest authority in the Philippines with executive, legislative, and judicial powers.

questions.question: What was the typical term of office for a Spanish Governor-General in the Philippines?
questions.explanation: The Governor-General typically served for 3-6 years and resided in Malacañang Palace in Manila, representing the Spanish Crown.

questions.question: What was the 'gobernadorcillo' in the Spanish colonial system?
options: A little governor or town mayor
questions.explanation: The gobernadorcillo was the town mayor selected from the principalia class who served without salary for two years and was responsible for peace and order.

questions.question: What was the 'polo y servicio' system?
questions.explanation: Polo y servicio was a forced labor system requiring males aged 16-60 to work for 40 days annually without pay, which could be commuted by paying 1.5 pesos.

questions.question: What was the 'bandala' system?
options: Forced sale of products to government
questions.explanation: The bandala system forced farmers to sell rice and other products to the government at below-market prices, creating artificial scarcity and high food prices.

questions.question: Which social class held the highest positions in government and church during Spanish colonial rule?
questions.explanation: Peninsulares were Spaniards born in Spain who occupied the highest positions in government and church, enjoying the greatest privileges and social status.

questions.question: What was the difference between Peninsulares and Insulares?
options: Peninsulares were military, Insulares were civilians
Peninsulares were born in Spain, Insulares were Spaniards born in the Philippines
Peninsulares were wealthy, Insulares were poor
Peninsulares were priests, Insulares were government officials
questions.explanation: Peninsulares were Spaniards born in Spain with the highest status, while Insulares (Creoles) were Spaniards born in the Philippines who felt marginalized by peninsulares.

questions.question: What does 'Mestizo de Sangley' refer to?
questions.explanation: Mestizo de Sangley refers to people of Filipino-Chinese descent who dominated retail trade and commerce but faced periodic persecution and restrictions.

questions.question: What were the 'Tornatras' in colonial Philippine society?
options: People of mixed Spanish, Chinese, and Filipino descent
questions.explanation: Tornatras were people of complex heritage with Spanish, Chinese, and Filipino descent, creating unique social challenges as they navigated multiple cultural identities.

questions.question: Who were the 'Principalia' in colonial Philippine society?
questions.explanation: The Principalia were the native Filipino aristocracy, including former datus, wealthy landowners, and local officials who enjoyed privileges like exemption from tribute and forced labor.

questions.question: What characterized the 'Ilustrados' class?
options: They were the educated Filipino class
questions.explanation: The Ilustrados were the educated Filipino class, often from principalia or mestizo families, who studied in prestigious schools and became leaders of reform and independence movements.

questions.question: What was the majority class of native Filipinos called during Spanish colonial rule?
questions.explanation: The 'Indios' were the vast majority of native Filipinos - farmers, laborers, artisans, and fishermen who were subject to tribute, forced labor, and various taxes.

questions.question: Where were Chinese immigrants (Sangleys) forced to live in Manila?
questions.explanation: Chinese immigrants were forced to live in designated areas like the Parian in Manila, despite their crucial roles in Philippine commerce.

questions.question: Which religious orders controlled most parishes and educational institutions?
questions.explanation: The five major religious orders - Augustinians, Dominicans, Franciscans, Jesuits, and Recollects - controlled most parishes, owned extensive estates, and dominated education.

questions.question: What was the primary source of the Catholic Church's economic power in colonial Philippines?
questions.explanation: The Catholic Church owned vast haciendas and agricultural estates, controlling some of the most fertile lands and collecting rent from Filipino tenant farmers.

questions.question: What was the 'Secularization Movement' about?
options: Replacing Spanish friars with Filipino secular priests
questions.explanation: The Secularization Movement demanded replacing Spanish friars with Filipino secular priests, leading to tensions between Spanish religious orders and Filipino clergy.

questions.question: Who were Gomez, Burgos, and Zamora (GOMBURZA)?
questions.explanation: GOMBURZA were Filipino priests executed in 1872 on charges of sedition. This event galvanized Filipino nationalism and anti-friar sentiment.

questions.question: What was the oldest university in Asia established during Spanish colonial rule?
options: Colegio de San Juan de Letran
questions.explanation: The University of Santo Tomas, founded in 1611 and run by the Dominican Order, is the oldest university in Asia.

questions.question: Which institution was known for more progressive education and where José Rizal studied?
options: Colegio de San Juan de Letran
questions.explanation: The Ateneo Municipal de Manila, run by Jesuits since 1859, was more progressive with better academic standards and discipline, where José Rizal received excellent education.

questions.question: What was the main problem with primary education during Spanish colonial rule?
options: Limited to towns with Spanish presence
questions.explanation: Primary education was limited to towns with Spanish presence, with most rural areas lacking formal schools and higher enrollment only in Manila and major cities.

questions.question: What was the Educational Decree of 1863?
options: It established a public education system
questions.explanation: The Educational Decree of 1863 established a public education system, marking a significant change from previous limited educational access.

questions.question: What was the 'Galleon Trade' that connected Manila to Acapulco?
options: Annual trade between Philippines and Mexico
questions.explanation: The Galleon Trade (1565-1815) was annual trade between Manila and Acapulco, with Manila serving as an entrepôt for Asian goods traded for Mexican silver.

questions.question: When did the Galleon Trade end?
questions.explanation: The Galleon Trade ended in 1815 due to competition and changing global trade patterns, after operating from 1565-1815.

questions.question: When was Manila opened to world trade?
questions.explanation: Manila was opened to world trade in 1834, ending the trade monopoly and allowing direct trade with Europe, America, and other Asian countries.

questions.question: What were the major export crops that grew after opening Manila to world trade?
questions.explanation: After 1834, sugar, tobacco, and abaca (Manila hemp) became major export crops, leading to the growth of export agriculture.

questions.question: What was the tobacco monopoly period in the Philippines?
questions.explanation: The tobacco monopoly operated from 1782-1881, with the government controlling tobacco production and trade as a major revenue source.

questions.question: What was 'abaca' also known as?
questions.explanation: Abaca was also known as Manila hemp, an important fiber export crop that became significant in the 19th century Philippine economy.

questions.question: What economic system granted land and native labor to Spanish settlers?
questions.explanation: The encomienda system granted land and labor to Spanish settlers, creating concentrated land ownership and rural inequality.

questions.question: Who typically worked as tenants or laborers on large estates?
questions.explanation: Filipino farmers mostly worked as tenants or laborers on Spanish-owned lands and church haciendas, creating a system of rural inequality.

questions.question: What often caused periodic famines in colonial Philippines?
options: The bandala system and focus on export crops
questions.explanation: The bandala system and focus on export crops over food production led to periodic food shortages and famines, especially during bad harvests.

legacy.title: Legacy
legacy.description: Questions about Rizal's impact and commemoration

questions.question: Which prominent American said Rizal was 'the greatest man the Malayan race has produced'?
questions.explanation: Austin Craig, an American educator and author, praised Rizal as 'the greatest man the Malayan race has produced'.

questions.question: What scientific genus was named after Rizal?
questions.explanation: Both the genus 'Rizalia' (a type of beetle) and 'Draco rizali' (a flying lizard) were named in honor of José Rizal.

questions.question: How many countries have Rizal monuments or streets named after him?
questions.explanation: Over 25 countries worldwide have monuments, streets, or landmarks named after José Rizal, showing his global impact.

questions.question: What prestigious international award recognized Rizal posthumously?
options: Knight of the Order of Isabella the Catholic
questions.explanation: Japan awarded Rizal the Order of the Rising Sun posthumously, recognizing his influence on Asian nationalism.

questions.question: Which university established the first Rizal chair in the world?
questions.explanation: Heidelberg University in Germany established the first chair dedicated to José Rizal studies, reflecting his international academic importance.

questions.question: What is the name of the tallest monument to Rizal?
questions.explanation: The tallest Rizal monument is located in Wilhelmsfeld, Germany, standing as a testament to his time studying there.

questions.question: Which of Rizal's quotes is most widely known worldwide?
options: 'He who does not love his own language is worse than an animal and smelly fish'
'The youth is the hope of our future'
'My fellow citizens of a country that has never been free'
'To die for the sake of one's country is glorious'
questions.explanation: 'The youth is the hope of our future' (Ang kabataan ang siyang pag-asa ng bayan) is Rizal's most internationally recognized quote.

questions.question: What type of currency features Rizal in the Philippines?
questions.explanation: José Rizal appears on both the 1-peso coin and 1-peso bill in the Philippines, making him a daily presence in Filipino life.

questions.question: Which international organization recognized Rizal Day as a cultural celebration?
questions.explanation: UNESCO recognized Rizal Day as a significant cultural celebration, acknowledging its importance in promoting cultural heritage.

questions.question: What is the name of the international award given for Rizal studies?
questions.explanation: The Order of Rizal is an international award given to individuals who have made significant contributions to Rizal studies and promotion of his ideals.
